channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: For His 3rd Term, Xi Jinping Surrounds Himself With Loyalists
item.description: The men who were chosen have longstanding ties with Mr. Xi. For the first time in decades, no woman was chosen for the party’s Politburo, the policymaking body.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: New members of the Politburo Standing Committee being introduced at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, on Sunday.

item.title: China Hangs on Xi’s Every Word. His Silence Also Speaks Volumes.
item.description: At the important Communist Party congress this week, the Chinese leader didn’t mention two long-repeated maxims. To many, it’s a warning of the turbulent times ahead.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, is expected to secure a precedent-defying third term at the end of the Communist Party congress.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Pulls Ahead With Votes in UK Prime Minister Race
item.description: Conservative Party lawmakers have so far put more weight behind Rishi Sunak to be their next leader, but Boris Johnson is still in the fight to reclaim Downing Street.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak in July at a Conservative Party event in Leeds, England.

item.title: ‘We Heard It, We Saw It, Then We Opened Fire’
item.description: With an intense, hastily assembled effort, the Ukrainian military is pioneering successful techniques in the difficult art of anti-drone warfare.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Police officers in Kyiv, Ukraine, trying to shoot down a drone during an attack on Oct. 17. The drone was believed to be an Iranian-made Shahed-136, purchased by Russia in August.

item.title: Frontline Fight Intensifies Even as Russia Targets Infrastructure
item.description: With winter on the way, Russia and Ukraine are locked in heavy exchanges of fire all along the front in urgent attempts to make gains.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident clearing debris from an apartment damaged by Russian bombardment in the city of Nikopol, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Using Adoptions, Russia Turns Ukrainian Children Into Spoils of War
item.description: Thousands of Ukrainian children have been transferred to Russia. “I didn’t want to go,” one girl told The New York Times from a foster home near Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A broken window at a hospital in March in Mariupol, Ukraine. Russian officials have made clear that their goal is to replace any childhood attachment to home with a love for Russia.

item.title: Russian Superyachts in Turkey Raise Concerns in Washington
item.description: Turkey’s welcoming ports are symptoms of a much larger problem: evasion of U.S. sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Elif Ince, Michael Forsythe and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Elif Ince for The New York Times
item.media:description: Solaris, a superyacht linked to the Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich, in the Yalıkavak Bay in Bodrum, Turkey, in August.

item.title: How Political Primaries Drive Britain’s Dysfunction
item.description: In the United States, too, the rise of inside-party primaries has empowered candidates at the extremes, and the result is likely to be a greater disconnect with the public.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: 10 Downing Street in London, where Prime Minister Liz Truss resigned this week. Ms. Truss was only the fourth British leader to win the job through a party primary.

item.title: How Tumultuous Forces of Brexit Divided U.K.’s Conservative Party
item.description: Some experts link Liz Truss’s downfall to the ripple effect of Britain’s departure from the European Union and the bitter, ideologically opposed factions it created in her party.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brexit supporters gathering in front of a statue of Winston Churchill in London on Jan. 21, 2020, to celebrate Britain leaving the European Union.

item.title: Hu Jintao’s Departure Causes Stir as Xi Elevates Loyalists in Congress
item.description: A new lineup of the Communist Party elite will limit potential resistance to Mr. Xi’s agenda of bolstering security and expanding state sway over the economy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Xi Jinping with Premier Li Keqiang, center, and the Politburo Standing Committee member Wang Yang during the closing ceremony of the party congress. Both Mr. Li and Mr. Wang stepped down from the Central Committee, indicating that both are set to retire.

item.title: Ukraine War Amputees Find New Limbs, and Hope
item.description: It did not take long for amputees to begin coming off the Ukrainian battlefield. Our photographer captured their fight to lead ordinary lives again.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fellow soldiers, their loved ones, and hospital staff. gather in the hallway with curiosity and to show support for Semyon, 27, as he takes his first steps on his new leg prosthetic leg in the hallway of a hospital in the town of Truscavets on August 26, 2022. By his side is his wife Vika, 24. Semyon, who is a radio operator and signalman for the 11 anti-aircraft misslie battery. lost his leg to a Russian mortar barrage in Ukraine’s Kharkiv region. He says that his unit was shelled 43 times in 20 minutes between 6:20-6:40 am on that day. Was born in Reni, in the Odesa region and has been a professional combatant for the Ukrainian military since 2019.

item.title: Hassles of Cross-Border Trains Hamper EU’s Green Ambitions
item.description: One man is on a mission to find and suggest fixes for all of the flaws making international rail travel in Europe surprisingly hard. Getting more people on trains is key to meeting E.U. climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the railway station in Rumburk, Czech Republic, on the border with Germany. “We need to get more people on trains,” said Jon Worth, the self-appointed monitor of Europe’s railroad system.

item.title: Russia Hits Ukraine’s Power Infrastructure
item.description: Ukrainian officials confirmed missile strikes in at least half a dozen regions, and the country’s state energy company imposed restrictions in several areas.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from part of an intercepted Russian missile in the center of Zaporizhzia, Ukraine, this week.

item.title: Airline Quits U.K. Plan to Deport Asylum Seekers to Rwanda
item.description: Amid protests, Privilege Style said it would stop running the deportation flights as part of Britain’s highly criticized effort. The move has left the deal in further disarray.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Migrants who were picked up at sea while trying to cross the English Channel. Thousands of people have made that journey in small boats this year seeking asylum.

item.title: Ngo Vinh Long, Lightning Rod for Opposing the Vietnam War, Dies at 78
item.description: After escaping arrest in Vietnam for his antiwar views, he became the most prominent Vietnamese in the United States to campaign against the war.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans

item.title: Xi Jinping Now Holds Near-Absolute Power in China, Creating Risks
item.description: Xi Jinping has created a new ruling elite packed with loyalist officials primed to elevate his agenda of bolstering national security and of turning China into a technological great power.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Chang Che
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, left, with new members of the Politburo Standing Committee at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Fighter Jet Crashes Into a Home in Serbia, Killing Two Pilots
item.description: The crash in Irkutsk was the second of a Russian warplane in a residential area within a week.
item.dc:creator: Matt Surman
item.media:description: Irkutsk, Russia, after a fighter jet crashed into a residential area on Sunday.

item.title: Republicans’ Persistent 2020 Election Doubts
item.description: Hundreds of Republicans running for offices this year have questioned the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu

item.title: China’s Politburo Has No Women, a Break With Custom
item.description: For the first time in decades, the Politburo has no female members. And no woman has ever been included in the even more exclusive and powerful Standing Committee.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Shen Yiqin, the party secretary of Guizhou Province, at the party congress on Saturday.

item.title: Russian Authorities Tell Civilians to ‘Immediately’ Leave Kherson
item.description: Kherson, which was captured by Russia early in the war, is a major industrial port city and the capital of the one of the four regions Russia has illegally annexed.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Civilians relocated from the Russian-controlled city of Kherson arriving by ferry in Oleshky, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: A loyal aide in Shanghai takes a leading role in Beijing.
item.description: Li Qiang is now China’s second-highest official after Xi Jinping. Mr. Li’s time in Shanghai had raised questions about whether he would rise to the party’s highest levels.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Li Qiang, the Communist Party chief of Shanghai, at the opening of the party congress in Beijing.

item.title: How China’s top leadership is selected.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: A meeting of Communist Party leaders last week. The party’s most important decisions on top positions are often made through back-room dealings.

item.title: Xi is expected to unveil a new lineup of top officials.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: China’s President Xi Jinping and other senior members of the government raised their hands to vote during the closing session of the party congress in Beijing, on Saturday.

item.title: Hu Jintao Was Escorted Out of China’s Congress, Raising Questions
item.description: A health scare? A brazen political gesture? Whatever else it was, the episode was awkward.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:description: The unexpected departure of a former leader, Hu Jintao, standing, who apparently paused to speak to Mr. Xi before being escorted out, caused a brief stir during in proceedings that are usually tightly choreographed.

item.title: Hurricane Roslyn Hits Mexico as a Category 3 Storm
item.description: The storm brought coastal flooding and dangerous winds to cities along the country’s Pacific Coast, killing at least one person.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Hurricane Roslyn flooded streets in Puerto Vallarta, in Mexico’s Jalisco state, on Sunday.

item.title: Ian Hamilton, 97, Who Stole a Scottish Relic From Westminster Abbey, Dies
item.description: In an audacious caper, he and three other Scottish nationalists liberated the Stone of Destiny nearly 700 years after England had seized it from Scotland.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Ian Hamilton in 1951. To him, the theft was the rightful repatriation of a symbol of Scottish independence.

item.title: Boris Johnson Returns to Britain and Gains Support for Prime Minister Bid
item.description: The former Conservative leader, who was forced out of office after scandals this summer, hasn’t declared his candidacy, but dozens of party lawmakers already support him.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Boris Johnson on Saturday at Gatwick Airport near London after returning from a vacation. While he was away, Prime Minister Liz Truss resigned.

item.title: Some Palestinians Move Into Caves to Resist Israeli Expulsion
item.description: Israel’s Supreme Court has ordered the removal of about 1,200 Palestinians from their villages in the occupied West Bank. The United Nations says that could amount to a war crime.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Abu Sabha family in July inside a cave in Khirbet al-Fakheit, a village in the West Bank. The family’s home was destroyed three times, so they turned to the cave.

item.title: Did the Pandemic Change Your Personality? Possibly.
item.description: For more than two years, Covid disrupted social rituals and rites of passage. Now a recent study suggests we have become less extroverted, creative, agreeable and conscientious. The declines in some traits were sharper among young people.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucy Nguyen participates in a group scream at the Zionsville Youth Soccer Fields in Whitestown, Indiana.

item.title: Scare Tactics
item.description: It’s Halloween season, time for two-pound bags of fun-size candy and scary movies that haunt your dreams.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Getting People Back on Trains, After the Pandemic Turned Many to Cars
item.description: While the federal government is committed to a multibillion-dollar improvement to train service, an already long schedule may face delays.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The federal government has said it is committed to a new passenger rail line through Ontario and Quebec.

item.title: Zar Amir Ebrahimi, an Iranian Exile, Channels Trauma in ‘Holy Spider’
item.description: Zar Amir Ebrahimi, who had to flee Iran after an intimate tape was leaked, has been transfixed by the protests erupting there as her film “Holy Spider” is released in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times

item.title: Cultural Bereavement: Naming the Grief Refugees May Feel
item.description: There is a name for the specific type of grief that both refugees and migrants experience. It’s called “cultural bereavement.”
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Theo Stroomer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tamara Plieshkova reunited with her granddaughter in Colorado after escaping the war in Ukraine in September.

item.title: Russian Troops in Belarus Spur Debate Over the Threat to Ukraine
item.description: The United States and its allies are playing down the dangers posed by the deployment of thousands of Russian soldiers to Belarus, but the intelligence assessments come with a dose of uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus during a joint military exercise in Asipovichy, with Russian forces, a week before the invasion of Ukraine in February.

item.title: Zelensky Accuses Russia of Deliberately Slowing Grain Shipments
item.description: The U.N. confirmed a backlog of 150 ships waiting to fulfill contracts to transport Ukrainian food products, a delay that comes as a deadline to renew a grain deal nears.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: Ellie M, a cargo ship carrying Ukrainian corn, awaiting an inspection while anchored off Istanbul last week.

item.title: How a Prison Fire Unfolded in Iran
item.description: The cause of the fire last weekend remains unclear, but witnesses and families of prisoners say that the authorities had been bracing for unrest in the notorious Evin Prison in northern Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Wana News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: The aftermath of the Oct. 15 fire in Evin Prison, on Monday.

item.title: Giorgia Meloni Gets Go-Ahead for New Italian Government
item.description: The hard-right leader will be sworn in on Saturday as the country’s first female prime minister amid questions about her coalition’s commitment to Europe.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni speaking to the media in Rome on Friday after receiving a mandate from President Sergio Mattarella to form a government.

item.title: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s Ex-Leader, Is Barred From Office
item.description: The decision by Pakistan’s election commission is a major escalation of the showdown between the ruling establishment and Mr. Khan, and it raises the specter of unrest.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan in September outside a court in Islamabad.

item.title: Security Forces Open Fire on Protesters in Chad, Killing at Least 50
item.description: Demonstrators had taken to the streets, demanding that the ruling military junta stick to its promises to hold elections.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Mahamat Adamou
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Anti-government demonstrators set a barricade on fire during clashes in N’Djamena, Chad, on Thursday.

item.title: Swedish Speed Cameras Keep Getting Stolen. Is It Russia?
item.description: The disappearance of the pricey cameras from rural roads is a mystery. Theories abound on why the cameras have become such a target.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Alexander Mahmoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Driving near Sävsjö, Sweden. There are 2,300 speed cameras across the country, and drivers who are caught speeding get a ticket in the mail.

item.title: British Lawmaker Quits After Watchdog Finds Him Guilty of Sexual Misconduct
item.description: The findings came after a complaint from a junior staffer that the lawmaker, Christian Matheson, had made unwanted advances on her. Mr. Matheson denied any sexual misconduct, but resigned.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Chris Matheson, a member of Parliament with the Labour Party, resigned on Thursday.

item.title: Who Will the Next U.K. Prime Minister Be and How Will They Be Chosen?
item.description: The process, which does not include the general public, will be swift, with plans to have a result by next week.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Britain could have a new prime minister as soon as Monday.

item.title: Ukrainians Brace for a Cold Winter Amid Russian Conflict
item.description: In cities and towns battered by the war, residents worry about how to heat their homes as temperatures drop. But even in places spared from the worst of the fighting, Russian strikes on infrastructure have raised new fears.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Brazilian Official Granted Power to Order Removal of Misinformation Online
item.description: Brazilian authorities granted the country’s elections chief broad power to order the takedown of online content in a bid to combat soaring misinformation ahead of this month’s election.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexandre de Moraes, a Supreme Court justice in Brazil who leads the nation’s electoral court, will now have broad power to order tech companies to remove content.

item.title: Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak Are Top Contenders for UK Prime Minister
item.description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the man who helped oust him from his job, the former Finance Minister Rishi Sunak, are seen as two of the top contenders within the governing Conservative Party.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The door to 10 Downing Street in London, the prime minister’s office and residence.

item.title: Liz Truss’s Downfall
item.description: Liz Truss is inflation’s latest political victim, and probably not its last.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Liz Truss.

item.title: 5 Australian Women Sue Qatar Over Invasive Searches at Airport
item.description: The women say that they have suffered lasting trauma from the episode and are pushing for policy changes.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Hamad International Airport in Doha, Qatar, in 2018.

item.title: How Australia Fell Behind on Data Privacy
item.description: A recent spate of cyberattacks have highlighted the nation’s relatively lax approach to safeguarding personal data. But change may be on the way.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: An Optus store in Sydney’s central business district this week. A data breach at the company was the largest in Australian history.

item.title: Could Boris Johnson Make a Comeback as UK Prime Minister?
item.description: A comeback by Mr. Johnson is viewed as a very real possibility, delighting some Conservative Party lawmakers and repelling others.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Cough Syrup: What We Know About Tainted Medicine from India
item.description: Tainted syrup from India may be connected to the deaths of dozens of children in Gambia, officials said. Indonesia banned cough syrup sales, though the link there is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: A notice at a pharmacy in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday announcing that the sale of medicinal syrup had been halted.

item.title: She’s Inheriting Millions. She Wants Her Wealth Taxed Away.
item.description: Marlene Engelhorn, 30, heir to a fortune, isn’t interested in philanthropy, believing it only perpetuates existing power dynamics. She’s calling for structural change to how the ultrarich are taxed.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy
item.media:credit: Mashid Mohadjerin for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The dream scenario is I get taxed,” said Ms. Engelhorn, the co-founder of a group called Tax Me Now.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Liz Truss resigns.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: As Inflation Stalks Europe, Leaders Shudder
item.description: The downfall of Britain’s prime minister served as a warning to all of the political peril that awaits those who fail to address the erosion of living standards, no matter the cause.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in Milan. The incoming government of Giorgia Meloni will have to struggle with how to cushion inflation’s blow in Italy without inflating already bloated deficits.

item.title: Ukraine Rations Power Despite Battle Gains in Kherson
item.description: Russia may be preparing to retreat from the southern city of Kherson, Western analysts say, but Ukraine’s president warned of possible destruction of a dam upstream.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Monika Pronczuk and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Podil neighborhood of Kyiv on Thursday. The government asked Ukrainians to cut back on energy usage to ensure enough heat and light during the coming winter months.

item.title: Liz Truss Resigns After 6 Chaotic Weeks, Igniting New Leadership Fight
item.description: The beleaguered British prime minister relinquished her office after just 44 days of political and economic tumult, the shortest tenure in British history.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Liz Truss announced her intention to resign as Britain’s prime minister outside 10 Downing Street in London on Thursday.

item.title: Liz Truss Is Eligible for a $129,000 Annual Allowance Despite Short Term
item.description: The departing British leader would be the sixth prime minister to receive the reimbursement for her expenses after leaving office.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss is eligible for the Public Duty Costs Allowance, a reimbursement of expenses incurred after she leaves office.

item.title: Russian Errors Prompted Deployment of Iranian Drone Personnel to Ukraine, U.S. Says
item.description: John Kirby, a National Security Council official, also warned that Russia may try to buy advanced missiles from Iran.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and John Ismay
item.media:description: A drone believed to be an Iranian Shahed-136, which explodes on impact, nearing a target in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Warns Russia Plans to Blow Up a Major Dam in a ‘False Flag’ Attack
item.description: The Ukrainian president called for an international observation mission at the dam’s hydroelectric plant to prevent a potential catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Russian soldiers guarding the Kakhovka Hydroelectric Power Plant on the Dnipro River in Ukraine’s Kherson region in May.
